Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Hepatitis B or Hepatitis C infection
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Rickettsial infections (e.g., Rocky Mountain spotted fever)
Rheumatoid arthritis (with renal involvement and systemic manifestations)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with synovitis, thrombocytopenia, skin changes, and neurological manifestations such as seizures.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This condition is characterized by thrombosis and thrombocytopenia and can be associated with lupus. It may also lead to seizures due to cerebral involvement.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.rationale: While RA is primarily known for causing synovitis, it can also have systemic involvement including skin lesions and, rarely, hematological abnormalities like thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD can present with features of several autoimmune diseases including synovitis, skin rashes, thrombocytopenia, and neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Certain types of vasculitis can cause skin changes, joint inflammation, thrombocytopenia, and neurological complications including seizures.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This rare autoimmune disorder combines autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia, and it can be associated with other autoimmune conditions that cause symptoms like synovitis and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: Though more known for muscle weakness and skin changes, dermatomyositis can also present with synovitis and, rarely, hematological issues or seizures as part of a paraneoplastic syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Behçet's can present with skin lesions, arthritis (including synovitis), thrombocytopenia, and neurological symptoms such as seizures, known as neuro-Behçet's.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis can manifest in numerous organs leading to a wide range of symptoms including erythema nodosum (a type of erythematous-violaceous lesion), arthritis, and, less commonly, seizures.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily affecting the skin, systemic sclerosis can have widespread effects including joint inflammation, vascular abnormalities, and, in rare cases, thrombocytopenia and seizures.

diagnoses: Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia combined with Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura)
Schizophrenia (in the context of concurrent infection or hematologic abnormality)

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.reason: Symptoms including diarrhea and potentially altered taste perception (rare) can correlate with IBS, although not directly associated with dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.reason: Celiac disease can cause diarrhea. While less common, it can also impact neurological functions potentially influencing dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
diagnoses.reason: Conditions like Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis can cause diarrhea. Other systemic symptoms could potentially relate to the other listed symptoms indirectly.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension-associated Renal Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Chronic kidney disease can lead to hypertension and can sometimes be associated with electrolyte imbalances, potentially causing dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Hyperparathyroidism
diagnoses.reason: Can cause hypertension and influence calcium metabolism, possibly explaining some neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.reason: A neurological condition that can potentially explain dysgeusia and spasticity (related to blepharospasm), although its direct connection to the other symptoms is less clear.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: An autoimmune disease that can cause dysgeusia due to dry mouth. While primarily affecting moisture-producing glands, systemic involvement can potentially relate to other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Neurological Conditions Influencing the Cranial Nerves
diagnoses.reason: Conditions like Bell’s palsy or cranial neuropathies might explain dysgeusia and blepharospasm but are less directly associated with the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Endocrine Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Disorders affecting hormone balance, such as thyroid diseases, could potentially explain a broad range of symptoms including hypertension and menstrual-related issues possibly linked to endometriosis.

diagnoses.name: Primary Hypertension with Secondary Complications
diagnoses.reason: While primary hypertension itself is unlikely to account for all the listed symptoms, secondary complications affecting the kidneys, heart, and other vascular territories could indirectly relate to a wider symptomatology.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Vitamin C Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Vitamin C deficiency can lead to scurvy, which is associated with symptoms like easy bleeding, gum disease (periodontal disease), and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Chronic kidney disease can lead to a buildup of toxins in the body, which can cause symptoms such as irritability, easy bleeding, and epistaxis due to platelet dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Hemophilia
diagnoses.description: Hemophilia is a rare genetic disorder that impairs the body's ability to make blood clots, leading to symptoms such as easy bleeding and epistaxis.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: Leukemia is a type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow, leading to symptoms like easy bleeding, epistaxis, and irritability due to anemia or infections.

diagnoses.name: von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.description: This is a bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency in or impairment of a protein vital for blood clotting, leading to symptoms like easy bleeding and epistaxis.

diagnoses.name: Liver Disease
diagnoses.description: Liver disease can impair the production of blood clotting factors, leading to symptoms such as easy bleeding and epistaxis. It can also cause irritability due to ammonia buildup in the body.

diagnoses.name: Thrombocytopenia
diagnoses.description: Thrombocytopenia is a condition characterized by a low platelet count, leading to easy bleeding and epistaxis.

diagnoses.name: Gingivitis and Periodontitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the gums can lead to periodontal disease, characterized by gums that easily bleed. It's often a sign of poor oral hygiene but can be related to systemic health issues.

diagnoses.name: Acute Stress Reaction
diagnoses.description: Acute stress can manifest physically and psychologically, leading to irritability, and in some cases, can exacerbate conditions like periodontal disease due to neglect of oral hygiene or contribute to epistaxis through elevated blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin K Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Vitamin K is crucial for blood clotting. Deficiency can lead to symptoms like easy bleeding and epistaxis. It may also indirectly affect oral health though poor nutrition.

diagnoses.name: Autonomic neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of neuropathy affecting the nerves that help control the involuntary functions of the body, which relates to dysautonomias and could influence the balance of electrolytes.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder that can lead to atherosclerosis, dysautonomias, and abnormal electrolyte balances due to the effects of high blood sugar over time.

diagnoses.name: Sepsis
diagnoses.description: A severe infection that can spread throughout the body. In the context of having a urinary tract infection, sepsis could lead to dysautonomias and abnormal electrolytes as the body attempts to fight the infection.

diagnoses.name: Multiple system atrophy (MSA)
diagnoses.description: A rare neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic function and can present dysautonomias and abnormal electrolyte balances.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.description: A rare tumor of the adrenal glands that can cause flushing, abnormal electrolytes, and could potentially influence the development of dysautonomias.

diagnoses.name: Primary aldosteronism (Conn's syndrome)
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the adrenal glands characterized by excess production of aldosterone, leading to hypertension, atherosclerosis, and abnormal electrolytes.

diagnoses.name: Chronic kidney disease (CKD)
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over time. It can cause dysautonomias, abnormal electrolytes, and contributes to atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation and tissue damage throughout the body, affecting the urinary tract, cardiovascular system, and can lead to dysautonomias.

diagnoses.name: Autonomic dysreflexia
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs in individuals with spinal cord injuries, causing a sudden onset of excessively high blood pressure, flushing, and potential dysautonomias.

diagnoses.name: Carcinoid syndrome
diagnoses.description: A syndrome caused by carcinoid tumors, which release substances into the bloodstream leading to flushing, abnormal electrolytes, and can potentially cause dysautonomias.

diagnoses.name: Hashimoto's thyroiditis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that can cause hypothyroidism, with potential symptoms including mood lability and attention deficit issues.

diagnoses.name: Chronic fatigue syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. Symptoms might overlap with mood lability and attention deficit.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts on the outer edges. Though primarily a female disorder, its hormonal imbalances can indirectly cause mood lability and attention deficit.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life. Can be linked with hypothyroidism.

diagnoses.name: Bipolar disorder
diagnoses.description: A disorder associated with episodes of mood swings ranging from depressive lows to manic highs. Mood lability is a core feature.

diagnoses.name: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: A brain disorder marked by an ongoing pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that interferes with functioning or development.

diagnoses.name: Cystic fibrosis
diagnoses.description: An inherited disorder that causes severe damage to the lungs, digestive system and other organs in the body. It might be a stretch, but lung cysts and respiratory issues could vaguely connect to laryngitis symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of mental illnesses that cause constant and overwhelming anxiety and fear. Such disorders can also contribute to mood lability and possibly impact attention.

diagnoses.name: Laryngopharyngeal reflux (LPR)
diagnoses.description: A condition in which acid that is made in the stomach travels up the esophagus (swallowing tube) and gets to the throat. Symptoms can include those similar to laryngitis.

diagnoses.name: Graves' Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that leads to overactivity of the thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism). Features may include anxiety, weight loss, changes in menstrual cycles, enlarged thyroid gland, fatigue, and in some cases, the presence of cysts.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A condition that affects a woman’s hormone levels, leading to the development of cysts on the ovaries, obesity, and could potentially cause fatigue and mood disorders, including anxiety or depression which may manifest as obsessive-compulsive behavior.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Nodules
diagnoses.description: Solid or fluid-filled cysts that form within your thyroid, a small gland located at the base of your neck, above your breastbone. Most aren't serious and don't cause symptoms. Hyperthyroidism may develop in some cases.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Thyroid Disease
diagnoses.description: Comprises several conditions like Graves’ disease and Hashimoto’s thyroiditis that cause thyroid dysfunction. It can lead to symptoms like fatigue, weight changes, and in Graves’ disease, psychiatric manifestations might include anxiety or obsessive-compulsive behavior.

diagnoses.name: Ovarian Cysts
diagnoses.description: Fluid-filled sacs or pockets in an ovary or on its surface. Women have two ovaries — each about the size and shape of an almond — located on each side of the uterus. Symptoms can include bloating, discomfort, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue may worsen with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest. This condition might co-exist with psychological conditions like obsessive-compulsive disorder.

diagnoses.name: Pituitary Tumors
diagnoses.description: Abnormal growths that develop in the pituitary gland. Some pituitary tumors can result in the overproduction of thyroid hormones (leading to symptoms of hyperthyroidism), along with fatigue and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1 (MEN1)
diagnoses.description: A rare hereditary condition that leads to tumors in the endocrine glands and the pancreas. The tumors can be benign or cancerous and can produce excessive hormones, potentially causing a variety of symptoms including hyperthyroidism, fatigue, and possibly the development of cysts.

diagnoses.name: Neurofibromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that causes tumors to form on nerve tissue. These tumors are usually noncancerous (benign), but sometimes can become cancerous (malignant). Complications can include learning disabilities, skin changes, and the development of cysts.

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
diagnoses.description: A psychiatric disorder characterized by unwanted, intrusive thoughts (obsessions) and repetitive, ritualistic behaviors (compulsions). While not directly associated with hyperthyroidism, fatigue, or cysts, the stress of coping with other symptoms may exacerbate or reveal OCD tendencies in patients.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder that results in recurrent attacks of angioedema, but can also present with hypoglycemia due to gastrointestinal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder characterized by high blood sugar levels over a prolonged period. Hypoglycemia can occur as a complication of treatment or other factors.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms can include hypoglycemia, constipation, and sometimes angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B)
diagnoses.description: A genetic condition associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytomas, mucosal neuromas, and a marfanoid habitus. It can present with angioedema and constipation.

diagnoses.name: Insulinoma
diagnoses.description: A rare tumor of the pancreas that causes an overproduction of insulin, leading to hypoglycemia. It might indirectly relate to other symptoms due to its effect on metabolic processes.

diagnoses.name: Amyloidosis
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases where there is an abnormal deposition of amyloid proteins in tissues and organs. Gastrointestinal amyloidosis can cause constipation and hypoglycemia due to the destruction of islet cells.

diagnoses.name: Carbohydrate-deficient glycoprotein syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of inherited metabolic disorders that affect the body’s ability to glycosylate proteins properly, leading to a wide range of symptoms including hypoglycemia and gastrointestinal issues.

diagnoses.name: Functional Gastrointestinal Disorder
diagnoses.description: A variety of conditions that impair the regular movement of the digestive system, causing symptoms like constipation without an identifiable cause. Secondary symptoms could potentially mimic or trigger the other reported symptoms indirectly.

diagnoses.name: Neurological Disorders
diagnoses.description: Various neurological conditions can lead to symptoms like blepharospasm. Some conditions might also indirectly affect blood sugar levels and digestive health.

diagnoses.name: Porphyria
diagnoses.description: A group of liver disorders in which substances called porphyrins build up, negatively affecting the skin or nervous system. Some forms can cause abdominal pain, constipation, and might be associated with sugar metabolism disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation throughout the body, potentially affecting skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. Symptoms can vary and include fatigue, joint pain, rash, and fever. The combination of leukopenia (low white blood cell count) and decreased immunoglobulins may suggest an autoimmune process.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare, genetic disorder characterized by severe swelling (angioedema) in various parts of the body, including the extremities, face, and gastrointestinal tract. It is caused by a deficiency or malfunction of the C1 inhibitor protein and is not typically associated with hives or itching.

diagnoses.name: Hypersensitivity Reactions
diagnoses.description: Reactions can range from mild to severe and include various symptoms such as angioedema, palpitations (possibly due to anaphylaxis), and possibly congestion. These symptoms might occur due to allergen exposure and could potentially be associated with changes in white blood cell counts due to the body's immune response.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immunodeficiency
diagnoses.description: An immunodeficiency disorder characterized by decreased levels of several immunoglobulin (antibody) classes. This leads to an increased susceptibility to infections. Patients may experience a range of symptoms including those related to recurrent infections (e.g., lung infections), and in some cases, autoimmune phenomena.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects blood and bone marrow, characterized by the overproduction of abnormal white blood cells. Symptoms can include fatigue, fever, bleeding or bruising easily, frequent infections, and weight loss. Leukopenia may be observed in chronic lymphocytic leukemia, where mature white blood cells are dysfunctional.

diagnoses.name: Chemical Exposure
diagnoses.description: Exposure to certain chemicals, such as pesticides or solvents, can cause a range of symptoms including leukopenia, angioedema (as part of an allergic reaction), and palpitations. Chronic exposure may lead to more systemic effects, including immunosuppression.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by the overproduction of eosinophils, a type of white blood cell. It can cause damage to multiple organs including the heart and nervous system. Symptoms may include fatigue, cough, rashes, and in severe cases, heart damage that can lead to palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder affecting the immune system, characterized by the inability to properly regulate the number of immune cells, which leads to lymphoproliferation and autoimmune problems. Symptoms may include enlarged lymph nodes or spleen, autoimmune cytopenias, and increased risk of lymphoma.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that targets the peripheral nerves, leading to muscle weakness and sensory loss. While not directly related to the symptoms listed, autoimmune conditions can have widespread systemic effects, including hematologic abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that affects the lymphatic system. Symptoms can be varied depending on the type of lymphoma and where it is located in the body but may include enlarged lymph nodes, fever, night sweats, weight loss, and fatigue. Leukopenia may occur, depending on the disease's impact on bone marrow function.

diagnoses: Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (EGPA, formerly Churg-Strauss Syndrome)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)

diagnoses.name: Allergic reaction
diagnoses.description: An exaggerated response of the immune system to a substance, which can cause symptoms like nasal congestion, pruritis (itching), angioedema (swelling under the skin), and hypotension (low blood pressure).

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can cause pruritis, angioedema, hypotension, and nasal congestion as part of its presentation.

diagnoses.name: Chronic idiopathic urticaria
diagnoses.description: A condition where hives or angioedema (without weals) occur without known reason, potentially accompanied by symptoms such as pruritis and, in severe cases, could be associated with hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema), which might be accompanied by pruritis, but typically does not involve urticaria (hives). Hypotension can occur during severe episodes.

diagnoses.name: Drug reaction
diagnoses.description: Adverse reaction to medication, which can manifest as nasal congestion, pruritis, angioedema, and hypotension, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Acute urinary retention
diagnoses.description: A sudden inability to urinate, causing painful bladder distention and potential secondary reflex hypotension. Incontinence may occur as overflow incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Atopic dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A chronic skin condition characterized by itchy, inflamed skin. While it commonly presents with pruritis, in severe systemic cases or due to complications, one might observe angioedema or secondary nasal congestion.

diagnoses.name: Contact dermatitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic or irritant reaction causing a skin rash, characterized by pruritis, and possibly leading to secondary symptoms like angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Neurogenic bladder
diagnoses.description: A urinary disorder in which the bladder does not empty properly, possibly leading to incontinence. Associated symptoms can sometimes include hypotension due to autonomic nervous system dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including rash (which can itch, thus pruritis), nasal congestion, and in severe cases, hypotension due to cardiovascular involvement. Kidney involvement can lead to incontinence issues.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Systemic allergic reaction to food or drugs

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disease that can affect various organs and systems in the body, presenting with symptoms like skin rashes, oral ulcers, and potentially involving the heart (pericardial effusion) and nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.details: A chronic condition causing inflammation of the blood vessels, leading to symptoms including oral ulcers, skin problems, and can also affect the nervous system and heart.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.details: A group of disorders that destroy blood vessels by inflammation. Depending on the specific type, it can cause symptoms like mononeuritis multiplex, skin rashes, and involvement of the heart.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.details: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash, though less commonly associated with mononeuritis multiplex, it can present with similar systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Bullous Pemphigoid
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disorder that causes large, fluid-filled blisters. It primarily affects the skin and, in rare cases, can be associated with systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.details: A disorder that may include features of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including symptoms such as rashes, heart involvement, and neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disease primarily affecting the joints but can also have systemic manifestations such as skin lesions, neuropathies, and heart involvement.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disease affecting the glands that produce saliva and tears, potentially leading to nerve damage and heart involvement, although skin rashes are less common.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.details: A type of vasculitis that affects medium-sized arteries, leading to symptoms including nerve damage, skin lesions, and, sometimes, heart involvement.

diagnoses.name: Erythema Multiforme
diagnoses.details: An allergic reaction or infection-related condition causing skin lesions and rashes. Less typically associated with the complex combination of symptoms listed, but can occur in severe cases.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (EGPA, formerly Churg-Strauss Syndrome)
